div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddag but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrical Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express to Switzerland, Paris and London. Leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 2 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostendo. The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

div.head: INTERNATIONALISM IN SPORT IN EGYPT
div.p: MONDAY, JUNE 11, 1906

At the ceremony in connection with the laying of the foundation-stone of the Victoria College Lord Cromer showed his desire to create a feeling of general goodwill among the different nationalities whom fate has drawn together in Egypt. After twenty years and more of his influence we have seen the country emerge from a state of governmental chaos to a position in the world second to none in general prosperity. In spite of this there has been little tendency in times past for the Europeans to sink their petty party jealousies and to lay aside old differences and unite either socially or in any other way. Perhaps the English residents are to some extent responsible for this. Although not wishing to generalize like Mr. G. K. Chesterton, who in a recent issue of the "Illustrated London News" stigmatises the whole English people as snobs and respecters of persons, those of us who have lived long in Egypt cannot but admit that the English have been inclined to stand aloof from their fellows. There has been no honest attempt in Egypt to adopt the feeling in England and France which finds expression in the "entente cordiale." Although each nationality will probably alway retain its own characteristics it might be possible to break down in some measure the old ingrained idea that the English, so to speak, stand and always wish to stand alone.

In sport, in which the English have certainly taken the lead, there has been a tendency of late for other nationalities to take more than a passing interest. The impetus given to international sports by the success, of the Olympic Games at Athens, largely through the efforts of the King of Greece, backed up by oar own King Edward VII., has not passed unnoticed in Egypt Also the natives have taken to some of oar games, and have already acquired some proficiency in one form of sport at least,—football. The present Governor of Alexandria, Ibady Pacha, did much whilst at Port Said to encourage this game among the natives. Many a hard-fought game the pupils of the Arab School put up against the English, Maltese, and other teams there. It was soon noticed that for individual play many of the natives were man for man the equals and often the superiors of their opponents. In spite of the prophecies of pessimists against the advisability of attempting to put a team composed of different nationalities in the held, such an experiment was made. On that occasion Ibady Pacha himself kicked off, a fact which gave great pleasure to both natives and Europeans as showing his interest in the recreation of the residents. Against the best team H.M.S. Diana could put on the held, the united team, consisting of four natives, five Englishmen, and two Maltese, played a draw. After that occasionally each team would draw on flyers from other teams in special encounters.

It was noticed also that towards the end of the season the natives benefited much in their play from learning the art of combination. So proficient did some of the players become that if the game is taken up with the same enthusiasm in future years as the young natives now show, one may some day sees team of "All Arabs" fit to meet a first class English team, and we may yet witness something like a repetition of the triumphs of the original team of Maories, who visited England in the 'eighties.

It has been said that international cricket and football does more to draw the-colonies and the mother-country together than any Colonial Conference has done or ever can do. On the turf and under it all are equal, and it may be that the encouragement of international games in Egypt will do much to make the different nationalities appreciate the fact that in the sight of God all come into the world equally helpless and all leave the world in thy same condition. In sport at least there should be no artificial barriers of nationality and caste, in other walks of life there must always be distinctions, but in manly sports there is a common ground on which all can start off the same mark. The public- spirited enthusiast who would give a cup or other trophy for competition at football among native teams would not only be a missionary of enlightened civilization but assisting even a minor degree by the aid of sport the universal brotherhood of man, the ideal of the dreamer and the despair of those who have seen much and lived long.

div.head: Public Health Department
div.p: Mr. George Hogarty McLaren and Najib Eff. Shamiyah have been authorised to practise as doctors in Egypt.

div.head: Was It Madness?
div.p: A native was arrested about 1 p.m. on Saturday for throwing a large stone through the window of M. Magnin's jewellery shop in Cherif Pasha-street. On arrest he feigned madness.

div.head: Murder.
div.p: Advices from Damanhour report that the body of a fellah, half roasted, was found on Saturday, near Sontees, in the Behera. The fellah, whose body bore marks of violence, belonged to the esbet Hafiz. The police have instituted an enquiry.

div.head: No. 3 Palaoe Sold.
div.p: It is said that Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha has sold his palace, commonly known as No. 3, situated at Hadra, to the Building Lands of Egypt, Limited, but at what price is not known. His Excellency intends to erect a new palace on the site he recently purchased at Ramleh.

div.head: Village Fight.
div.p: News comes from Kom-Hamada to the effect that an affray took place, three days ago, among the inhabitants of the villages of Dest and Khanizet, in which several persons were severely wounded. The Moudir and the Damanhour Parquet authorities appeared on the scene and many arrests were made.

div.head: P.W.D. Adjudications.
div.p: The following tenders have been accepted by the Public Works Departments: Ibrahim Farghal, construction of an agricultural road 17 km. long between Galioub and Shibin-el Kantara along the railway line; Mr. Vittorio Rigano, construction of new irrigation offices at Mansourah; Mr. Geronimo Fucile, construction of a markaz with a police barracks at Kafr el Chark.

div.head: Travels of a Nile Lizard.
div.p: A resident of Cottingham, in Yorkshire, recently caught a large Egyptian lizard in his garden. "It is presumed that the animal was brought over in a steamer to Hull, and escaped," we are informed. Here, at any rate, there seems to be no doubt on the question of domicile. But how did the lizard of old Nile get across to Cottingham? If it landed in Hull, it had still some five miles In a N.W. direction to go in order to quarter itself in Cottingham. Students of the mysticism of the Orient might conjecture that this Egyptian lizard was really the Cottingham gentleman's Ks, which had looked in for a visit. As to that we venture no opinion. (''Daily News.")

div.head: The Bribe that Failed.
div.p: "Al-Zaher" makes the following statement: Owing to his son being sentenced to imprisonment for some crime, a rich native of Sama-lout Markaz, who hoped to obtain a decoration from H.H. the Khedive, recently requested some notable of the same village to intervene on his behalf and on behalf of his son. The notable promised to obtain a decoration for the father and to secure the release of the son at the same time, charging him a matter of L.E. 500 for the service. The father did not hesitate to pay, expecting a speedy fulfilment of the notable's promise. His expectations have been dashed by the fact that 'his son is now in gaol and that he has received no decoration or grade.

div.head: Gymnastic Display.
div.p: St. Joseph's College, Bacos, was en fete yesterday for the gymnastic exercises, which in every way, if a comparison may be permitted, outshone those held on Thursday at St. Louis, Rosetta-Gate. The French Vice- Consul, M. A. Ravalli, presided, and there were beside him on the platform surveying the play-ground (which was arranged in the form of a stadium) representatives of the Governor of Alexandria, the sister colleges, the press, and various communities. The band of St. Catherine's College supplied the musical part of the entertainment, and successfully performed a choice repertoire, which greatly encouraged the youthful gymnasts, who looked extremely natty in their tricolour uniforms. The events were twenty-two, including an amusing sack-race ; and were divided into field sports and gymnastic exercises. The whole was under the direction of Mr. H. C. Tookey, who looked every inch an athlete. He certainly has infused in to the college the essence of discipline, which is the aim of all athletics, and the rounds of applause which were showered upon his pupil were no less meant for him. But the person who, above all, deserves the fullest need of praise is the indefatigable fere director of the college, to whose efforts in a large measure is due the success of yesterday's exhibition. After the distribution of prizes, the jury presented a silver cup to Mr. H. C. Tookey, in testimony of their appreciation of his services.

div.head: Commercial and Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head:
CONGO REFORMS.
KING LEOPOLD'S PACIFIC CONQUEST.

div.p: The report on the Congo Free State, embodying the results of the Committee of Enquiry, was published here. It announces many reforms, including the extension of the paid labour system, although the natives are compelled to give their services to works which are for the public utility ; it prohibits military operations by commercial companies ; it provides for the taxing of profits of foreign companies to the extent of one per cent. and Congolese companies, two per cent. ; a prize of £8,000 is offered for a cure for sleeping sick- ness.
King Leopold, in a covering letter, says that his pacific conquest of the Congo is made only on behalf of Belgium and that no Power has the right of intervention. (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTROGERMAN ALLIANCE. A VALUABLE GUARANTEE OF PEACE.

div.p: The Austrian Delegation has appointed M. Lobkovicz as president. (Havas)

The Emperor Francis Joseph, receiving the Austro-Hungarian Delegation, referred to the German alliance, which, he said, owing to its defensive character, was a valuable guarantee of peace. The visit of the Emperor William to Vienna again placed on record their intimate friendly relations, which were of an equally trustful nature as those with their other ally, Italy. (Reuter)
The Emperor, on receiving the Delegation, referred to the solidity of the Austro-German Alliance. (Havas)

An inspired article in the "Grenzbote" urges that the Bagdad railway famishes an excellent opportunity for the conclusion of an Anglo-German agreement. It protests that Germany's interest is purely economic whereas Britain's is political. The construction of the railway, it states, signifies the strengthening of the Mohamedan world, with which Britain has largely to reckon. (Reuter)

div.head: THE DUMA. DISCUSSING THE AGRARIAN QUESTION.

div.p: The Duma is heatedly discussing the agrarian question. The representative of the Labour Party declared that the Ministers had been driven out but had refused to budge ; they had, he said, neither shame nor conscience. The attempt of the President to call him to order was drowned in cheering. (Reuter)
The resignation of the Goremykine Cabinet is denied.The Duma is debating on the agrarian question. (Havas)
Bands of terrorists yesterday evening simultaneously pillaged 23 Government alcohol stores and barned five. The troops intervened and sixteen persons were killed or wonnded. (Reuter)

div.head: GOVERNMENT AND CHINESE LABOUR. INDIGNATION AMONG RADICALS.

div.p: House of Commons. —Mr. Churchill's speech, in connection with the Colonial Office vote on the Labourite motion to reduce Lord Elgin's salary, was talked out. If a division had been taken the Government majority would probably have sunk to its lowest ebb, owing to indignation among the Radicals regarding the Chinese Labour Policy. (Reuter)

The "Daily Chronicle," which is the only Ministerialist paper defending the Government's Chinese policy, states that Mr. Churchill's speech is generally regarded as improving the situation in the Transvaal. (Reuter)
Dinizulu has expressed the wish to come to Pietermaritzburg to interview the Governor, but owing to ill-health he is sending his trusted indunas instead. (Reuter)
As a result of the retirement of the regicides, Great Britain has agreed to the appointment of M. Militchevitch, hitherto the Berlin Servian Minister, as Servian Minister in London. (Reuter)
King Oscar has decided not to be represented at the coronation of the King of Norway. (R.)

div.head: ARRIVAL IN CONSTANTINOPLE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has arrived. (Havas)
CONSTANTINOPLE, June 10.
The Khedive arrived yesterday and lunched at the Palace. He afterwards drove to his residence on the Bosphorus. (Reuter)

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has conferred grades and decorations on several officials who have retired on pension. Mabmoud Sofwat Bey, director of the Tanzim, Gharbieh, receives the rank of Montemaiz. The Sanieh is conferred on Mohamed Hanafi Bey, chief of the Arabic Department of the State Railway Administration, Cairo ; and the same grade on Khorshid Wessim Bey, inspector of Balkas Teftiche, State Domains. Constantin Eff. Hanna, employe in the Government Printing Offioe, has received the Medjidieh of the 5th class.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECREES.
div.p: Saturday's "Offioial Journal" contains the following decrees :—
1. A decree raising the pay of 2nd lieutenants in the Egyptian Army to L.E. 6 per mensem (L.E. 8 in the Sudan) and of 1st lieutenants to L.E. 7 per mensem (L.E. 9 in the Sudan).
2. A decree authorising the construction of two bridges over the Sayalah Draw at El Khohak and another over the El Ramadi Canal at El Sebaieh, in the Assouan province.
3. A decree authorising the construction of a railway signal box at Miniet el Sireg, Kaliou- bieh.
4. Authorisation of the enlargement of the left embankment of the El Rashwanieh Canal, Ghirgeh province.
5. Authorisation of the construction of a new station at Aga, on the light railway between Mit Ghamr and Mansoorah.
6. Authorisation of the expropriation of land at Tamalai for a new Moslem cemetery.

div.head: MURDER SENTENCES.
div.p: The Native Court of Alexandria, yesterday, sentenced Ali Nagi, a native of Simikhrat, Shnbrakhit Markaz, to imprisonment with hard labour for life, for murdering Ali El Kaski, of the same village, on the 24th April last; and sentenced Iskri Ibrahim Abousalem and Salem Ali, of the Ezbet Abdalla Bey Soffeir, Etai el-Barond Markaz, each to 10 years' imprisonment with hard labour, for impaling Mahrqas Salim, of the same ezbet, on the 3rd May last.

The Court also sentenced Abdel Nebli Ham- moudeh Darweesh, of Ezbet el-Makta, Abon Hommos Markaz to 5 years' imprisonment with hard labour for shooting his brother, Abdel Latif, on the 22nd April last with intent to kill.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The San Stefano baths will be opened on Wednesday next, on which day the public will be admitted gratis to enable them to visit the new establishments and installations which, among others, include a series of cabins de luxe. Beside the ladies' baths, a new basin has been made where children can bathe on the beach without any danger.

div.head: AHMED DJELALEDDIN PACHA.
div.p: One of our contemporaries publishes a letter in its last issue stating, in a tone of great assurance, that the Ottoman Government is highly displeased with the conduct of Mukhtar Pacha, and that it is only awaiting a favourable moment to recall the Ghazi. The letter goes on to say that General Ahmed Djelaled- din Pacha—who it will be remembered took refuge in Egypt two years ago, fleeing from Constantinople, where he was occupying the high but evidently unsafe post of chief of the Sultan's secret police—will be appointed successor to Mukhtar Pacha.

We are in a position to state that Ahmed Djelaleddin Pasha was approached by the Sultan five or six months ago with the object of finding oat whether he would accept the post in question, bat evidently an understanding could not be reached in this respect between Abdal Hamid and his rebellions subject.

Since then, and up to a very recent date, a regular state of hostilities has existed between former master and servant. Whether the Sultan has again extended the olive branch in the shape of a renewal of his former offer to Ahmed Djelaleddin Paoha, of whom he stands in dread for many reasons, and whether the Pacha is disposed to come to terms with him on the basis in question—which would surprise us—we do not know. What we do know, however, is that the post of Ottoman High Commissioner ceased to exist in the eyes of the British and Egyptian Governments from the day that Sir H. Drammond Wolff left Egypt as a result of the breakdown of the convention which Great Britain sought to conclude with Turkey through his intermediary for the settlement of the Egyptian Question.

The Sultan may appoint a successor to Mukhtar Pasha, and call him also High Commissioner, speeding even more of Turkey's money than heretofore ou his salary, bat whoever the gentleman may be he will not be recognized in/the above capacity by the Anglo-Egyptian authorities any more than Mukhtar Pacha has been.

div.head: CAPE-CAIRQ IN BIOSCOPE. NOVEL ENTERPRISE.
div.p: Mr. Brian Bellasis and Mr. Lionel Cooke are organising in London an expedition, which is being I supported by a number of important companies, the object of which is to obtain bioscopic records of the scenery along the route of/the Cape to Cairo Railway.
In addition to fulfilling the commercial mission which is the main purpose in view, the expedition will, at the request of the Zoological Society, endeavour to get specimens of rare animals.
Ethnological interests will be subserved by aiming phonographic records of the dialects of varions native races.

When Broken Hill, the terminas of the southern section of the railway, is reached, the real difficulty of the expedition will begin. For many months but slow progress can be made, with the aid of native bearers, and when the northern shores of Lake Victoria Nyanza are reached the presence of hostile natives and the extreme danger from fever will render the journey somewhat precarious.

In Abyssinia the Emperor Menelik will be visited, and animated pictures of London will be shown to him, in return for which it is hoped permission will be granted to bring home to London records of lite in the most gorgeons Court in Africa.
From Abyssinia the expedition will strike back to the Nile, and proceed by steamer and rail to Cairo.

div.head: BISHOP POTTER PRAISES BRITISH RULE.
div.p: Bishop Potter, of New York, was a few days ago the guest of "The Pilgrims" at a dinner given at the Hotel Cecil, London. In reply to the toast of "The Pilgrims of America and Our Guest," proposed by the Archbishop of Canterbury, Bishop Potter, who is President of the Pilgrims in America, referred to the fact that he had spent the winter in Egypt. He said that after witnessing what Great Britain had done in this country, he did not know whether it would be any comfort for them to know that the American Eagle was going about the streets with its tail between its legs. He was in Egypt 30 years ago, and he had to confess that such a transformation had come to pass that that once dark land was now completely changed. The characteristic that struck him in Egypt was the triumphant and splendid illustration, which the English had given not so much of sympathy as of justice. The rule of former great empires had been based first upon force, then upon what he should call blaster or menace, then upon chicanery, nowadays called diplomacy; but the thing that had made England great wherever she had ruled and colonised was not force or diplomacy, it was Justice. It was the adherence of the individual to his word and the maintenance of integrity in ordinary transactions. He believed profoundly that the future destiny of the human race was in the bands of Anglo-Saxon civilization.

In the course of an interview with "Tribune" correspondent, Bishop Potter said; "I have just Returned from Egypt, where you have been doing the best bit of work in your history. The thing which impressed me was that the British officer is as a rule incorruptible. You cannot buy him. The desire to make money is not one of those things which prompts him to do his duty. That is a product of his nurture in the Church of England."

div.head: SCHOONER CAPSIZES IN HARBOUR
div.p: A Turkish schooner with a cargo of timber from Adalia capsized yesterday afternoon near the Alexandria breakwater on entering the harbour. No lives were lost, the Greek crew being rescued by a ports and Lighthouses tender, which was immediately sent to the assistance of the vessel.
Efforts are being made to right her, and it is hoped they will be successful to-day.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: The cable ship Silvertown is still ashore in the Bay, and further efforts to refloat her have proved unsuccessful. She is now discharging her cargo of rice into lighters, after which she may get off. Her position at present is considered rather serious.
The Italian gunboat Barbarigo will sail from Suez to day for Port Sudan, for surveying purposes.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL REVENUE.
div.p: The report to be presented to the general meeting of shareholders of the Suez Canal Company fixed for to-morrow shows that the receipts from the traffic through the Canal in 1905 were about 2,100,000fr. less than in the preceding year. Considering, however, that the year 1904 was one of the most favourable which the company has had to record, the results of the last financial year, says the report, may be considered entirely satisfactory, and will permit of the dividend being maintained at 14lfr. net and the sum of 3,000,000fr. being added to the special reserve fund.

The total receipts for 1905 amounted to 117,308,l96fr., and the expenditure 40,984,184fr. Daring the year 4,116 ships, representing a tonnage of 13,134,105 tons passed through the Canal, being a decrease of 121 ships and 267,730 tons, as compared with 1904. The report goes on to say that, despite the increase in the dimensions of the ships using the Canal, navigation, owing the works carried out, has been rendered both safer and easier, as evidenced by the decrease in the number of ships going ashore. Power is asked to increase from 25,000,000fr. To 50,000,000fr. the loan, of which the share holders authorised the conclusion in 1901 to meet the cost of improvements, although the directors have hitherto not availed themselves of their authority.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Ministers will come down to Alexandria on the 20th inst. to spend the summer months at San Stefano.
M. Pacliano, the new Roumanian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General in Cairo, visited Mastapha Pacha Fehmy and the other Ministers on Saturday.
Sir William Garstin is leaving on the 16th inst. on ordinary leave of absence
Mr. Goschen, private secretary to Sir William, will also take 3 months' leave on the same date.

The death took place at Alexandria yesterday, after a very brief illness, of Aly Bey Fakhry, Counsellor at the Mixed Court of Ap- 1. The funeral of the deceased will take place this afternoon. On Saturday last he was present in Court.
Ali Eff. Djamal-ei Din, sub-Governor of Ismailia has been granted leave for two months.
M. Laisnd, directing engineer for the construction of Boulac Bridge, will be back on the 15th inst. from his mission to London and Paris.
Mr. John A. M. Bonar, secretary to Mr. Smedley Norton, has left for Eirope by the S. S. Mombassa.
H.M. the Shah of Persia has conferred the Order of Khorshid (2nd class) on Ahmed Bey el Ilfi, Persian Vice Consul at Zagazig.
Yousbashi Hassan Husni Munib Eff., moawin of Kalioub Markaz, has been transferred to Alexandria , and Mulazim Awal Ibrahim Hamdi Eff. mulahiz of Koos Markaz, to Hehia Markaz.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port'Said, are: Mr. Sater, Mr. F. B. Toy, Mr. L. S. Milfar, Mr. C. E. Wolff, Dr. Smith, Mr. J. Eoxwolf, Mr. C. K. Beashy, Mr. W. R. B. div.head: AN APPEAL FOR THE TREES.
div.p: "A Lover of Trees" ( Cairo ) writes as follows :-

I shall be glad of a space in your columns in behalf of the trees. Avenue trees in Cairo are a luxury and every year become more precious, as the buildings increase, and each tree oughts to be cherished and given as fair a chance as possible. This I think is not done, and probably through ignorance, the trees are year by year ill-treated. New houses are built and the trees are surrounded with lime and stones, and die, or take their chance as it may be. But the principal evil is the stupid way the trees are chopped and destroyed each year at this season. The men and long ladders arrive, and all the lower branches are sawn, or torn off, and every bit of green, until the tree is bare, its branches bereft of all that make them useful, and beautiful, and it becomes an eyesore. The shade we all long for the tree cannot give, all the lower branches are gone and the upper ones are thin and bare. Go to Ghezireh or the Pyramid road and cast your eye on the trees there. Tall lanky stalks, towering to the sky, bare ugly branches with all the natural clothing in the way of green cut from them, and the shelter from the sun they are intended to give does not exist. The trees look quite indecent, and ashamed of themselves.

The Arabs who skin the trees neither know or care what they do, bat think they must take off as much as possible, and leave as little (possibly they are interested in the selling of the wood, or have it as a backsheesh !! ?).

There should be someone in authority over these men, someone, I mean, who has a little knowledge, and judgement, about the pruning and catting of trees, cutting out the dead wood, and leaving the young, taking away any branches that interfere with wires, or windows, yet leaving the tree bushy and thick over the roads ; at present it is apparently left entirely to the Arabs, who have orders to cut, and cat they do ; voila tout, and it will soon be, as far as the trees are concerned "Nichts, Rien, Nothing whatever." 1 know one of these Lebbek tree, which has never been cut,—it is beautiful! It has never had a worm in its bark, and its branches do not seem to break off like the chopped trees do. I have an idea that the worms that destroy these trees would not get into them if they were allowed a more natural growth and to shelter their own stems.
"All said and done
It's little I, against a throng.
I'm only one,
And possibly, I may be wrong."

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: The Madrid Outrage.
div.p: The news of the dastardly outrage which has marred the wedding festivities in Madrid will be received with feelings of horror and indignation throughout the civilized world, mingled with a sense of profound thankfulness at the almost miraculous escape of the young King and Queen.

The miscreant has, we learn, been arrested and his identity established. But, whatever his name and nationality, the atrocious act mast have been the deed of a madman, for no normally constituted human being could have been so dead to all the higher emotions as to ignore so ruthlessly the unconscious appeal of youth and happiness and universal gladness.

It is a cause for thankfulness that the assassin's murderous attempt was not made until after the wedding ceremony had been happily concluded, and that thus the Royal bride and bridegroom were spared the ordeal, which might well have proved too severe, of continuing their progress to the church with nerves shattered by the terrible danger through which they had passed. Nor can we doubt that the cruel experience which has befallen them on the threshold of their wedded life will but serve to draw the Royal pair more closely together, and to excite alike in the young King's chivalrous nature a determination to obliterate, by every means in his power, from his Queen's remembrance the scene which she was yesterday compelled to witness. In that endeavour he will be eagerly and enthusiastically seconded by the people which is now hers no less than his, and whose passionate anger and grief at what has happened will command the ready sympathy of the nation to which but yesterday Princess Ena belonged. ( 'Times.'')

div.head: The Derby.
div.p: A great institution truly is the Derby Day ! On it are we all sportsmen—and many who on all other days of the sombre year are free of reproach partake on it of the excitement of the gambler, be it only through the innocuous medium of the all-embracing sweep- stake. Yachts may sail the seas for a cup,motors scorch along dusty Toads for a trophy, and in the Stadium athletes compete for the laurel, but in public favour none of these compete with the horses on the Downs. ("Tribune.")

div.head: Lord Milner's "Bank of Praise."
div.p: Lord Milner, at the dinner of the Grocers' Company, said it was not always possible for a man who had tried to be faithful to his Government to be regarded-at first at any rate—with equally favourable eyes by a new Government and party. Personally he always felt the wisest thing to do was to bank the praise when one got it, live on it when blamed, and not make too much fuss about it either way. ("Daily Mail.")

div.head: Reduction of Armament.
div.p: The English are quite in a position to reduce the expenditure for their Navy altogether independently of other Powers, since their insular situation protects them from attacks, and their Navy will in all circumstances maintain its 'superiority over the other navies for many years to come. ("Frankfurter Zeitung.")

div.head: Naval Economy a Risk.
div.p: "For want of a rail the shoe was lost ; for want of a shoe the horse was lost"—we all know the crescendo of disaster by which we were taught in our childhood not to despise the day of small things. Therefore, the economy which would reduce the Navy even to the bare level of the two-Power standard is not to be encouraged by any true patriot. The stranding of the Montagu is just the sort of accident to guard against the consequences of which an ample margin is required. ("Standard.")

div.head: Germany v. The World.
div.p: The day Russia joins the coalition England is preparing against Germany will find Germany in an analogous position to that of France under Napoleon I.— alone against the world. ("France Militaire," Paris.) |

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Lieutenant Colonel A. M. Mantell, Royal Engineers, on returning home from Egypt about the end of July, will take up the duties of
R. E. of Cork Sub District.

Lieutenant the Hon. C. M. Hore-Ruthven, S.O., Black Watch, who recently was appointed to the Egyptian Army, has been promoted captain. His services have been already given in these notes. His elder brother, Lieutenant the Hon. A. G. A. Hore Ruthven, Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders, has been confirmed in his appointment of aide-de-camp to the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.

Second Lieutenant Geoghegan, who has just been appointed to the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers from the Militia, has been ordered to do duty with the 1st Battalion, Belfast, from the 30th inst. to the coming trooping season, when he will join the 2nd Battalion at Cairo.
Second Lieutenant E. C. N. Merriman and C. A. Fleury Teulon, 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, have been promoted lieutenants after two years and ten months' service.
Gentleman Cadet J. Mood, Sandhurst, has been appointed to the Royal Dublin Fusiliers as second lieutenant, and will, in the first instance, join the 1st Battalion at Buttevant.

Owing to the present extended formation of infantry the hearing of words of command has become a great difficulty. To remedy this experiments are being made with megaphones. It is said that these instruments have been employed with considerable success.

Four changes have taken effect in the command of cruisers. Captain S. E. Erskine has completed two years' service in the command of the Leander, and is succeeded by Captain J. 8. Luard ; Captain W.O. Boothby will relinquish the command of the Endymion, gunnery ship at Sheerness, and will be succeeded by Captain E. H. Grafton ; Captain C. Hunter will assume command of the Scylla; Captain A. S. Lafone will succeed Captain J. H. Hewitt in command of the Blake.

The battleship Africa, built at Chatham, has returned to Plymouth Soundy. upon the conclusion of thirty hours' steam trial, which she reported satisfactory. The Africa is under orders to leave the Sound for a further trial at 12,000 indicated horse power. The trials have been delayed by the fog in the Channel.

It is understood that the Channel Fleet, when the maneuvers, now in progress, are over, will pay a visit to Gothenburg, Sweden, The visit most likely will take place in the middle of July. Such a visit will no doubt raise comments in the German press.

div.head: THE TURKISH PRIORITY LOAN.
div.p: The Ottoman Bank (a Constantinople message states) has come to an agreement with the Porte on the subject of the conversion of the Priority Loan.

The bank offered to guarantee the entire proposed bond issue at the price of 86, but the Porte demanded 87. A compromise has been effected at 86}. An annuity of £T430,000, which will be set apart for the service of the new bonds, will admit of an issue to the total extent of £12.000,000, without the increase of the present charges to the Ottoman Treasury, The new bonds will be similar to those of the Unified Debt.
Those holders of present priority bonds, who do not approve of the conversion, will be entitled to an immediate redemption of their bonds in full.

div.head: GAMBLING ON OCEAN LINERS.
div.p: The sensational stories recently circulated of heavy losses by gambling on Atlantic liners have an interesting sequel in the action taken by one of the great steamship companies. The White Star Line have issued the following notice with their passenger lists :—

"The attention of the managers has been called to the fact that certain persons, believed to be professional gamblers, are in the habit of travelling to and fro in Atlantic steamships. In bringing this to the knowledge of travellers the managers, while not wishing in the slightest degree to interfere with the freedom of action of patron of the White Star Line, desire to invite their assistance in discouraging unes of chance as being likely to afford these individuals special opportunities for taking unfair advantage of others."

div.p: Cricket. Sussex v. Hampshire and Notts v. Essex. The matches were drawn.

Chesterfield, Derbyshire v. Yorkshire. Yorkshire won by 33 runs.
Leicester. Leicestershire v. Surrey. Surrey won by 110 runs.
Peterborough. Warwickshire v. Nothampton- shire. Warwickshire beat Northamptonshire by ten wickets.
Cambridge. Middlesex v. Cambridge University. Middlesex beat Cambridge by 189 runs.
(Reuter)
